text: With laying it doesn’t matter as it’s based on liability, with backing there is a risk but it evens out

text: The strategy was initially to try and reduce PC but eventually morphed into something profitable

elements.text: The strategy was initially to try and reduce PC but eventually morphed into something profitable

text: <@U4H19D1D2> The narrative is pushed heavily on Twitter by the likes of Joseph Buchdahl that closing lines are highly efficient. Yet to see him post any formal statistical analysis but I have not looked too hard as I don't believe it myself. I have done some simple analysis of favourites and how backing them at last traded price right before off compares with at X minutes before the off and as you say, the difference is not huge. I don't actually use BFSP as I don't ask for it on the API and don't record it as I never use it. I have back tested several strategies over the years based around this but none were profitable - until recently when the commission dropped to 2%

elements.text: The narrative is pushed heavily on Twitter by the likes of Joseph Buchdahl that closing lines are highly efficient. Yet to see him post any formal statistical analysis but I have not looked too hard as I don't believe it myself. I have done some simple analysis of favourites and how backing them at last traded price right before off compares with at X minutes before the off and as you say, the difference is not huge. I don't actually use BFSP as I don't ask for it on the API and don't record it as I never use it. I have back tested several strategies over the years based around this but none were profitable - until recently when the commission dropped to 2%

text: It is usally the crowd that have a big hard on for Pinnacle that promote this narrative. I have asked many times that if their analysts are the best and if analytics have improved over the years we should see an improvement in the efficiency of opening prices over the last X years but this seems to never be addressed. Also always seem to just cover US sports and football all of which are much easier to build a statistical model for than horse racing. I really think pre-off horse racing is an a tier of its own in that regard, as well as price action before the start.

I really think pre-off horse racing is an a tier of its own in that regard, as well as price action before the start.

text: You take a large enough sample it’s going to be efficient. Have you read his books? He’s obviously a clever guy but extremely narrow minded and openly admits that he doesn’t make money from gambling...

elements.text: You take a large enough sample it’s going to be efficient. Have you read his books? He’s obviously a clever guy but extremely narrow minded and openly admits that he doesn’t make money from gambling...

text: I have his sharps suckers squares (or whatever it is called) that I purchased well over a year ago but not yet read. After interacting with him on twitter and seeing his output I thought that I have better things to do than read an entire book on it. I would completely agree with your assessment of him. I am a mathematician and I am interested in statistical analysis and ML and such things but I want to use that to get an advantage - not try and prove that nobody else is able to. Too narrow a field of analysis too - soccer and US sports only. No treatment of exchanges either so no use to me. He always talks about bias - and his own is clear to see. It is like he doesn't WANT it to be possible to profit from gambling. The fact that he is often on twitter grizzling publicly about how bookies are mistreating him in regards to his affiliate accounts also leaves a lot to be desired. Reading that back it sounds like I have an axe to grind but I don't - his output and agenda are just not for me.

text:
Agreed, I enjoyed the first chapter but then just got frustrated. I think it might be a case of if he can’t make money then no one should be able to but that’s obviously not the case. 

Lots of noise about how efficient exchange markets are but if the ‘efficiency’ difference between 60/30/10/5 minutes is so small then it’s obviously a load of crap. You can make money from SP but you can obviously make a hell of a lot more if you beat it

text: Well that is the kind of thing I was hoping he might address - look at efficiency formally using something like chi-square p-values on prices at various time intervals and if their narrative is true we should see some convergence. If there is none but we have large changes in odds over those same intervals than obviously that widens the window of opportunity considerably. I guess he makes his money from selling books and as a lot of people tend to view gambling as something undesirable or "dirty" I suppose he has a good sized audience.

text: I posted this on BA forum a while ago but it is basically showing the profit of a strategy based on the time of order placement where -100 is BSP. As you can see there is more value at BSP then there is at 0 (scheduled start time)

text: It is an interesting chart as I have read a lot of stuff about the "smart" money entering no earlier than 2 minutes before off. No idea if there is any credibility to that but your chart does suggest that there is a price contraction from 5 minutes out (if I am reading the chart correctly)

No idea if there is any credibility to that but your chart does suggest that there is a price contraction from 5 minutes out (if I am reading the chart correctly)

text: Backing and laying, yeah that is what this chart is confirming

text: It is even more interesting as it suggests that provided you know what the "smart" selections are you can wait for the price move to occur and get on the train at any time and still be profitable!
